titlestmt.titleproper: The Register to the Betsy Jolas Papers
titlestmt.author: Richard Boursy and Emily Ferrigno, with Stefanie Acevedo, Mary Jones, and Julie Niemeyer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:00

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Franco-American composer Betsy Jolas ranks among the most distinguished and influential modern composers. She was born in Paris in 1926. Her American parents, Eugène and Maria Jolas edited Transition, an important literary journal. Betsy Jolas grew up in a literary environment, and from her childhood she was personally acquainted with many prominent writers, including James Joyce. As war came to France in 1940, the Jolas family moved to New York. Betsy studied at the Lycée Français in New York, and then at Bennington College in Vermont. She studied composition with Paul Boepple, piano with Helen Schnabel, and organ with Carl Weinrich. After the war, she returned to France. She married Gabriel Illouz in 1949; they had three children. At the Paris Conservatoire she studied under Darius Milhaud and Olivier Messiaen, the latter of whom she assisted and then succeeded as professor of analysis (1975) and professor of composition (1978). She has spent most of her career in France, but she retains dual citizenship in France and the United States. She has served as a visiting professor at several American universities, including Yale, and she is a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the American Academy of Arts & Sciences. (She has received many other awards and honors as well.) Jolas has composed numerous instrumental and vocal works in a wide variety of combinations. Her musical style was much influenced by Webern, as well as Boulez and Stockhausen. Her literary background is evident in her exploration of the relationships between words and music. She is the composer of four operas, Le pavillon au bord de la rivière, Le Cyclope, Schliemann, and Iliade l'amour.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Betsy Jolas Papers include music, correspondence, writings, teaching materials, programs, clippings, journals, calendars, photographs, sound recordings, awards and other materials by and about the composer Betsy Jolas. The first series in the collection contains manuscript and printed scores by Jolas and by other composers (1958-2006). Some of Jolas' scores are accompanied by production notes, scenarios, and libretti, and many of the scores she collected contain annotations. The second series contains correspondence (1937-2010), both personal and institutional. Jolas corresponded with notable figures from the American and French Avant-Garde, such as Pierre Boulez, Elliott Carter, Henri Dutilleux, and Darius Milhaud, all of whom are represented in this series. The third series contains teaching materials that Jolas used in her lengthy career as a university instructor. The fourth series, Writings (1963-2009), contains similar material, and also includes a "lesson in poetics" given to a young Jolas in 1940 by James Joyce. Series five (1943-2010) consists of programs for concerts, festivals, and award ceremonies, and Series six (1949-2009) contains related publicity materials and press releases. Series seven contains pocket calendars and personal journals; the latter are restricted until the death of Betsy Jolas. Series eight (1926-2006) includes both professional and personal photos of Jolas and others. Series nine is comprised of degrees earned by Jolas, and awards given to her, including the Legion d'Honneur (1996), and the Ordre National du Mérite (2001). The final series includes sound recordings and media in a variety of formats: test pressings, reel-to-reel tapes, cassettes, CDs, and DVDs. The recordings include a number of performances of Jolas' compositions, as well as interviews and lectures. Note that this series is organized by format.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers may also wish to consult the Eugène and Maria Jolas papers (GEN MSS 108) in the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library of Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Access to the journals of Betsy Jolas (Series VII.1), is restricted until her death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries: Music by Betsy Jolas, and Music by Others. The first subseries, the larger of the two, contains manuscript and printed scores of Jolas's own music. It is organized by genre; works are listed alphabetically within each genre. Materials include but are not limited to: manuscript originals and copies, libretti, scenarios and production notes, performance notes, typescripts and proofs with annotations, and published scores. The first subseries also includes arrangements and transcriptions by Jolas, as well as miscellaneous sketches and songs written for family members. The second subseries comprises published scores by various composers, organized alphabetically by the composer's last name. The majority of the scores contain analytical and historical annotations by Betsy Jolas. Also included are scores that are autographed or dedicated to Jolas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters, cards, and telegrams, and is organized alphabetically. There are two subseries: paper correspondence, and electronic correspondence. The series includes personal and institutional correspondence to and from Betsy Jolas, as well as other correspondence relevant to the name under which it is filed. Institutional correspondence is filed under the name of the institution, unless personal letters to the correspondent exist (in which case, all letters are filed under the name of the correspondent). Individuals of importance are cross-referenced. A few letters are filed by subject (piece title, festival, or award), in order to preserve the original order of the material. Most of the correspondence is in French or English. The series includes personal and artistic correspondence with notable figures from the American and French Avant-Garde, such as Gilbert Amy, Pierre Boulez, Elliott Carter, George Crumb, Henri Dutilleux, Olivier Messiaen, Darius Milhaud, Carol Plantamura, Bernard Rands, and Augusta Read Thomas. This series also features a variety of artists, writers, publishers, critics, academics, administrators, and heads of state. Notable arts institutions from both France and the United States are also represented in the series such as Radio France, Conservatoire National Supérieur de Musique de Paris, IRCAM/Centre Georges Pompidou, and Le Ministere de la Culture (France). Family correspondence is also included in this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries: Lecture Notes and Analytical Notes. Organized chronologically, the lecture notes are listed with their title and a location. Jolas's lectures address French music, 20th century composers, and various other musical subjects.
The analytical notes, or "notes d'analyse," are arranged alphabetically by composer. The notes feature composers such as J.S. Bach, Beethoven, Brahms, Stravinsky, Schoenberg and Xenakis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries: Writings by Jolas and Writings by Others. The first subseries includes writings and written drafts of presentations by Betsy Jolas. The second subseries includes both published works and original manuscripts--most notably, a "lesson in poetics" given to Jolas by James Joyce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists chiefly of programs for concerts in which Betsy Jolas performed or had works performed. Other items include conference/festival programs, brochures, programs for awards ceremonies, articles and newspaper reviews.

Organized by date, materials span Jolas's career from her earliest church, choir, and dance recitals through her 80th birthday celebration concerts and beyond. Events of note include performances at or by: Carnegie Hall/Lincoln Center, Tanglewood Festival, Chamber Music Society, Opera de Bastille, Opera de Paris, BBC Symphony Orchestra, Concord String Quartet, Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra, and Groupe Vocal de France. Ceremonial programs include the Prix Italia 1961, Cannes Film Festival 1980, and various honorary concerts.

did.unittitle: Clippings, publicity materials, documents, and scrapbooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, organized chronologically, contains articles, publicity materials, press releases, catalogs, and other memorabilia related to Betsy Jolas's career. The last subseries also includes miscellaneous personal documents. The series is divided into four subseries: Clippings, Publicity, Scrapbooks, and Miscellaneous Documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into two subseries, each organized by date. The Calendars subseries contains pocket calendars, address books, and compositional timelines. Some of the calendars include rehearsal times, concert setup, compositional notes and personal thoughts. Correspondence kept with the calendars is included in this subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the journals is restricted until the death of Betsy Jolas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into the following subseries: Jolas alone; Jolas with significant musical figures; Jolas with groups; Family; and Photos of others. Photographic prints constitute the bulk of the series. Camera film and slides have been digitized, and are indicated within the series by printed contact sheets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Betsy Jolas's awards, degrees, and related materials, organized by date. Awards include her 2001 Ordre National du Mérite and her 1996 Legion d'Honneur as well as programs and award certificates for membership induction into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (1995) and the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters (1983). Degrees include her Bachelor of Arts degree from Bennington College (1946) and her Dalcroze School of Music certification (1945). Also included are a Livret Scolaire (Student Report Book) from the Lycée Française de New York (1940-1942), and a French translation of her birth certificate (1946).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Three award certificates are rolled up, and included in this box.
